Dear recruiters, stop looking for candidates with 100% JD match.If someone matches your entire DevOps job description, you're chasing unicorns.Think about it.When you require 10+ years of Kubernetes (a technology from 2014), mastery of 3 different CI/CD tools, 4 logging/monitoring tools, 3 scripting language and expert-level knowledge across AWS, Azure, AND GCP... you're not describing a real candidate.You're describing a fantasy.And what happens when you actually find this rare specimen?They'll probably get bored and leave.The best DevOps engineers I've ever worked with weren't the ones who checked every technical box on day one. They were the ones who:- Demonstrated exceptional problem-solving skills- Had a genuine passion for automating everything- Possessed a "never stop learning" mindset- Understood that reliability matters more than fancy techMost skills in the DevOps world can be learned within weeks by someone with the right foundation.Hire engineers who meet 70-80% of your technical requirements but bring the right mindset.Focus on finding candidates who understand systems thinking, who approach infrastructure as code, who automate relentlessly, and who prioritize reliability. The specific tools are just implementation details.Stop chasing the perfect resume match. Start looking for the perfect mindset match instead.Your infrastructure (and your hiring timeline) will thank you.

Dear recruiters, stop looking for candidates with 100% JD match.If someone matches your entire DevOps job description, you're chasing unicorns.Think about it.When you require 10+ years of Kubernetes (a technology from 2014), mastery of 3 different CI/CD tools, 4 logging/monitoring tools, 3 scripting language and expert-level knowledge across AWS, Azure, AND GCP... you're not describing a real candidate.You're describing a fantasy.And what happens when you actually find this rare specimen?They'll probably get bored and leave.The best DevOps engineers I've ever worked with weren't the ones who checked every technical box on day one. They were the ones who:- Demonstrated exceptional problem-solving skills- Had a genuine passion for automating everything- Possessed a "never stop learning" mindset- Understood that reliability matters more than fancy techMost skills in the DevOps world can be learned within weeks by someone with the right foundation.Hire engineers who meet 70-80% of your technical requirements but bring the right mindset.Focus on finding candidates who understand systems thinking, who approach infrastructure as code, who automate relentlessly, and who prioritize reliability. The specific tools are just implementation details.Stop chasing the perfect resume match. Start looking for the perfect mindset match instead.Your infrastructure (and your hiring timeline) will thank you.

Dear recruiters, stop looking for candidates with 100% JD match.If someone matches your entire DevOps job description, you're chasing unicorns.Think about it.When you require 10+ years of Kubernetes (a technology from 2014), mastery of 3 different CI/CD tools, 4 logging/monitoring tools, 3 scripting language and expert-level knowledge across AWS, Azure, AND GCP... you're not describing a real candidate.You're describing a fantasy.And what happens when you actually find this rare specimen?They'll probably get bored and leave.The best DevOps engineers I've ever worked with weren't the ones who checked every technical box on day one. They were the ones who:- Demonstrated exceptional problem-solving skills- Had a genuine passion for automating everything- Possessed a "never stop learning" mindset- Understood that reliability matters more than fancy techMost skills in the DevOps world can be learned within weeks by someone with the right foundation.Hire engineers who meet 70-80% of your technical requirements but bring the right mindset.Focus on finding candidates who understand systems thinking, who approach infrastructure as code, who automate relentlessly, and who prioritize reliability. The specific tools are just implementation details.Stop chasing the perfect resume match. Start looking for the perfect mindset match instead.Your infrastructure (and your hiring timeline) will thank you.

Dear recruiters, stop looking for candidates with 100% JD match.If someone matches your entire DevOps job description, you're chasing unicorns.Think about it.When you require 10+ years of Kubernetes (a technology from 2014), mastery of 3 different CI/CD tools, 4 logging/monitoring tools, 3 scripting language and expert-level knowledge across AWS, Azure, AND GCP... you're not describing a real candidate.You're describing a fantasy.And what happens when you actually find this rare specimen?They'll probably get bored and leave.The best DevOps engineers I've ever worked with weren't the ones who checked every technical box on day one. They were the ones who:- Demonstrated exceptional problem-solving skills- Had a genuine passion for automating everything- Possessed a "never stop learning" mindset- Understood that reliability matters more than fancy techMost skills in the DevOps world can be learned within weeks by someone with the right foundation.Hire engineers who meet 70-80% of your technical requirements but bring the right mindset.Focus on finding candidates who understand systems thinking, who approach infrastructure as code, who automate relentlessly, and who prioritize reliability. The specific tools are just implementation details.Stop chasing the perfect resume match. Start looking for the perfect mindset match instead.Your infrastructure (and your hiring timeline) will thank you.

Dear recruiters, stop looking for candidates with 100% JD match.If someone matches your entire DevOps job description, you're chasing unicorns.Think about it.When you require 10+ years of Kubernetes (a technology from 2014), mastery of 3 different CI/CD tools, 4 logging/monitoring tools, 3 scripting language and expert-level knowledge across AWS, Azure, AND GCP... you're not describing a real candidate.You're describing a fantasy.And what happens when you actually find this rare specimen?They'll probably get bored and leave.The best DevOps engineers I've ever worked with weren't the ones who checked every technical box on day one. They were the ones who:- Demonstrated exceptional problem-solving skills- Had a genuine passion for automating everything- Possessed a "never stop learning" mindset- Understood that reliability matters more than fancy techMost skills in the DevOps world can be learned within weeks by someone with the right foundation.Hire engineers who meet 70-80% of your technical requirements but bring the right mindset.Focus on finding candidates who understand systems thinking, who approach infrastructure as code, who automate relentlessly, and who prioritize reliability. The specific tools are just implementation details.Stop chasing the perfect resume match. Start looking for the perfect mindset match instead.Your infrastructure (and your hiring timeline) will thank you.

Dear recruiters, stop looking for candidates with 100% JD match.If someone matches your entire DevOps job description, you're chasing unicorns.Think about it.When you require 10+ years of Kubernetes (a technology from 2014), mastery of 3 different CI/CD tools, 4 logging/monitoring tools, 3 scripting language and expert-level knowledge across AWS, Azure, AND GCP... you're not describing a real candidate.You're describing a fantasy.And what happens when you actually find this rare specimen?They'll probably get bored and leave.The best DevOps engineers I've ever worked with weren't the ones who checked every technical box on day one. They were the ones who:- Demonstrated exceptional problem-solving skills- Had a genuine passion for automating everything- Possessed a "never stop learning" mindset- Understood that reliability matters more than fancy techMost skills in the DevOps world can be learned within weeks by someone with the right foundation.Hire engineers who meet 70-80% of your technical requirements but bring the right mindset.Focus on finding candidates who understand systems thinking, who approach infrastructure as code, who automate relentlessly, and who prioritize reliability. The specific tools are just implementation details.Stop chasing the perfect resume match. Start looking for the perfect mindset match instead.Your infrastructure (and your hiring timeline) will thank you.

Dear recruiters, stop looking for candidates with 100% JD match.If someone matches your entire DevOps job description, you're chasing unicorns.Think about it.When you require 10+ years of Kubernetes (a technology from 2014), mastery of 3 different CI/CD tools, 4 logging/monitoring tools, 3 scripting language and expert-level knowledge across AWS, Azure, AND GCP... you're not describing a real candidate.You're describing a fantasy.And what happens when you actually find this rare specimen?They'll probably get bored and leave.The best DevOps engineers I've ever worked with weren't the ones who checked every technical box on day one. They were the ones who:- Demonstrated exceptional problem-solving skills- Had a genuine passion for automating everything- Possessed a "never stop learning" mindset- Understood that reliability matters more than fancy techMost skills in the DevOps world can be learned within weeks by someone with the right foundation.Hire engineers who meet 70-80% of your technical requirements but bring the right mindset.Focus on finding candidates who understand systems thinking, who approach infrastructure as code, who automate relentlessly, and who prioritize reliability. The specific tools are just implementation details.Stop chasing the perfect resume match. Start looking for the perfect mindset match instead.Your infrastructure (and your hiring timeline) will thank you.

Dear recruiters, stop looking for candidates with 100% JD match.If someone matches your entire DevOps job description, you're chasing unicorns.Think about it.When you require 10+ years of Kubernetes (a technology from 2014), mastery of 3 different CI/CD tools, 4 logging/monitoring tools, 3 scripting language and expert-level knowledge across AWS, Azure, AND GCP... you're not describing a real candidate.You're describing a fantasy.And what happens when you actually find this rare specimen?They'll probably get bored and leave.The best DevOps engineers I've ever worked with weren't the ones who checked every technical box on day one. They were the ones who:- Demonstrated exceptional problem-solving skills- Had a genuine passion for automating everything- Possessed a "never stop learning" mindset- Understood that reliability matters more than fancy techMost skills in the DevOps world can be learned within weeks by someone with the right foundation.Hire engineers who meet 70-80% of your technical requirements but bring the right mindset.Focus on finding candidates who understand systems thinking, who approach infrastructure as code, who automate relentlessly, and who prioritize reliability. The specific tools are just implementation details.Stop chasing the perfect resume match. Start looking for the perfect mindset match instead.Your infrastructure (and your hiring timeline) will thank you.

Dear recruiters, stop looking for candidates with 100% JD match.If someone matches your entire DevOps job description, you're chasing unicorns.Think about it.When you require 10+ years of Kubernetes (a technology from 2014), mastery of 3 different CI/CD tools, 4 logging/monitoring tools, 3 scripting language and expert-level knowledge across AWS, Azure, AND GCP... you're not describing a real candidate.You're describing a fantasy.And what happens when you actually find this rare specimen?They'll probably get bored and leave.The best DevOps engineers I've ever worked with weren't the ones who checked every technical box on day one. They were the ones who:- Demonstrated exceptional problem-solving skills- Had a genuine passion for automating everything- Possessed a "never stop learning" mindset- Understood that reliability matters more than fancy techMost skills in the DevOps world can be learned within weeks by someone with the right foundation.Hire engineers who meet 70-80% of your technical requirements but bring the right mindset.Focus on finding candidates who understand systems thinking, who approach infrastructure as code, who automate relentlessly, and who prioritize reliability. The specific tools are just implementation details.Stop chasing the perfect resume match. Start looking for the perfect mindset match instead.Your infrastructure (and your hiring timeline) will thank you.

Dear recruiters, stop looking for candidates with 100% JD match.If someone matches your entire DevOps job description, you're chasing unicorns.Think about it.When you require 10+ years of Kubernetes (a technology from 2014), mastery of 3 different CI/CD tools, 4 logging/monitoring tools, 3 scripting language and expert-level knowledge across AWS, Azure, AND GCP... you're not describing a real candidate.You're describing a fantasy.And what happens when you actually find this rare specimen?They'll probably get bored and leave.The best DevOps engineers I've ever worked with weren't the ones who checked every technical box on day one. They were the ones who:- Demonstrated exceptional problem-solving skills- Had a genuine passion for automating everything- Possessed a "never stop learning" mindset- Understood that reliability matters more than fancy techMost skills in the DevOps world can be learned within weeks by someone with the right foundation.Hire engineers who meet 70-80% of your technical requirements but bring the right mindset.Focus on finding candidates who understand systems thinking, who approach infrastructure as code, who automate relentlessly, and who prioritize reliability. The specific tools are just implementation details.Stop chasing the perfect resume match. Start looking for the perfect mindset match instead.Your infrastructure (and your hiring timeline) will thank you.

Dear recruiters, stop looking for candidates with 100% JD match.If someone matches your entire DevOps job description, you're chasing unicorns.Think about it.When you require 10+ years of Kubernetes (a technology from 2014), mastery of 3 different CI/CD tools, 4 logging/monitoring tools, 3 scripting language and expert-level knowledge across AWS, Azure, AND GCP... you're not describing a real candidate.You're describing a fantasy.And what happens when you actually find this rare specimen?They'll probably get bored and leave.The best DevOps engineers I've ever worked with weren't the ones who checked every technical box on day one. They were the ones who:- Demonstrated exceptional problem-solving skills- Had a genuine passion for automating everything- Possessed a "never stop learning" mindset- Understood that reliability matters more than fancy techMost skills in the DevOps world can be learned within weeks by someone with the right foundation.Hire engineers who meet 70-80% of your technical requirements but bring the right mindset.Focus on finding candidates who understand systems thinking, who approach infrastructure as code, who automate relentlessly, and who prioritize reliability. The specific tools are just implementation details.Stop chasing the perfect resume match. Start looking for the perfect mindset match instead.Your infrastructure (and your hiring timeline) will thank you.

Dear recruiters, stop looking for candidates with 100% JD match.If someone matches your entire DevOps job description, you're chasing unicorns.Think about it.When you require 10+ years of Kubernetes (a technology from 2014), mastery of 3 different CI/CD tools, 4 logging/monitoring tools, 3 scripting language and expert-level knowledge across AWS, Azure, AND GCP... you're not describing a real candidate.You're describing a fantasy.And what happens when you actually find this rare specimen?They'll probably get bored and leave.The best DevOps engineers I've ever worked with weren't the ones who checked every technical box on day one. They were the ones who:- Demonstrated exceptional problem-solving skills- Had a genuine passion for automating everything- Possessed a "never stop learning" mindset- Understood that reliability matters more than fancy techMost skills in the DevOps world can be learned within weeks by someone with the right foundation.Hire engineers who meet 70-80% of your technical requirements but bring the right mindset.Focus on finding candidates who understand systems thinking, who approach infrastructure as code, who automate relentlessly, and who prioritize reliability. The specific tools are just implementation details.Stop chasing the perfect resume match. Start looking for the perfect mindset match instead.Your infrastructure (and your hiring timeline) will thank you.

Dear recruiters, stop looking for candidates with 100% JD match.If someone matches your entire DevOps job description, you're chasing unicorns.Think about it.When you require 10+ years of Kubernetes (a technology from 2014), mastery of 3 different CI/CD tools, 4 logging/monitoring tools, 3 scripting language and expert-level knowledge across AWS, Azure, AND GCP... you're not describing a real candidate.You're describing a fantasy.And what happens when you actually find this rare specimen?They'll probably get bored and leave.The best DevOps engineers I've ever worked with weren't the ones who checked every technical box on day one. They were the ones who:- Demonstrated exceptional problem-solving skills- Had a genuine passion for automating everything- Possessed a "never stop learning" mindset- Understood that reliability matters more than fancy techMost skills in the DevOps world can be learned within weeks by someone with the right foundation.Hire engineers who meet 70-80% of your technical requirements but bring the right mindset.Focus on finding candidates who understand systems thinking, who approach infrastructure as code, who automate relentlessly, and who prioritize reliability. The specific tools are just implementation details.Stop chasing the perfect resume match. 🔥 ¿Realmente buscan talento o solo juegan con los candidatos?Después de varios procesos de selección, entrevistas y pruebas técnicas, quiero hablar de algo que, aunque todos sabemos que pasa, parece que nadie quiere decirlo en voz alta.✅ El guion siempre es el mismo:🔹 “¡Nos urge cerrar la vacante!”🔹 “Tu perfil es justo lo que buscamos.”🔹 “El proceso será rápido.”Te emocionas, te preparas, pasas entrevistas y pruebas técnicas (a veces largas y no pagadas)… y luego viene el infame silencio:❌ Correos sin responder.❌ Visto en WhatsApp.❌ Llamadas ignoradas.Y si logras que te respondan, siempre es la misma historia:🔸 “El cliente aún no decide.” (pero siguen entrevistando más gente)🔸 “El cliente canceló la vacante.” (pero sigue publicada una y otra vez)🔸 “Tu perfil es excelente, pero queremos evaluar más opciones.” (traducción: quieren pagar menos)🔸 “Estamos esperando aprobación.” (y seis meses después, la misma vacante sigue publicada)💼 Algunas verdades incómodas:📌 Piden 10 años de experiencia en tecnologías que existen hace 5.📌 Vacantes “urgentes” que terminan en procesos eternos o que mágicamente desaparecen.📌 Exigen un perfil Full Stack, pero con responsabilidades de DevOps, QA, SysAdmin y hasta Scrum Master, por un sueldo que apenas supera al de un becario.📌 Múltiples entrevistas, pruebas técnicas absurdas y exámenes interminables, solo para que al final elijan a alguien más barato o el proceso se cancele sin ninguna explicación.📌 “Buscamos el match perfecto”, pero cuando el candidato pide un sueldo acorde a su experiencia, mágicamente el presupuesto se reduce.📌 Piden honestidad en los CVs, pero no dan feedback, no responden mensajes y dejan a los candidatos en el limbo.💡 Entonces, ¿falta talento o falta estrategia en el reclutamiento?Se habla de escasez de talento, pero lo que realmente hay es:🚩 Procesos de selección mal estructurados.🚩 Expectativas irreales y sueldos que no corresponden con la experiencia requerida.🚩 Falta de compromiso con los candidatos.💼 A los reclutadores y headhunters:Si una vacante sigue abierta durante meses o años, tal vez el problema no es el candidato, sino su proceso de selección.Si ya entrevistaron a alguien y no lo seleccionaron, tengan la decencia de darle un cierre honesto en lugar de ignorarlo.No jueguen con el tiempo ni las esperanzas de las personas.📢 Candidatos, ¿les ha pasado? ¿Qué es lo más absurdo que les han dicho en un proceso de selección?Reclutadores, si creen que estoy equivocado, los leo en los comentarios. 👇hashtag#Reclutamiento hashtag#Hiring hashtag#RRHH hashtag#Respeto hashtag#Trabajo hashtag#TalentAcquisition hashtag#Candidatos hashtag#Transparencia hashtag#JusticiaLaboral hashtag#Recruitment hashtag#HiringProcess hashtag#TalentHunting hashtag#HRInsights hashtag#Headhunting hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#RecruitingFail hashtag#TrabajoDigno hashtag#JusticiaSalarial hashtag#WorkCulture hashtag#TrabajoRemoto hashtag#JobSeekers hashtag#Employment hashtag#CareerOpportunities hashtag#CandidateExperience hashtag#NoMásGhosting hashtag#FeedbackLaboral hashtag#RespetoLaboral hashtag#HiringTransparency

Dear recruiters, stop looking for candidates with 100% JD match.If someone matches your entire DevOps job description, you're chasing unicorns.Think about it.When you require 10+ years of Kubernetes (a technology from 2014), mastery of 3 different CI/CD tools, 4 logging/monitoring tools, 3 scripting language and expert-level knowledge across AWS, Azure, AND GCP... you're not describing a real candidate.You're describing a fantasy.And what happens when you actually find this rare specimen?They'll probably get bored and leave.The best DevOps engineers I've ever worked with weren't the ones who checked every technical box on day one. They were the ones who:- Demonstrated exceptional problem-solving skills- Had a genuine passion for automating everything- Possessed a "never stop learning" mindset- Understood that reliability matters more than fancy techMost skills in the DevOps world can be learned within weeks by someone with the right foundation.Hire engineers who meet 70-80% of your technical requirements but bring the right mindset.Focus on finding candidates who understand systems thinking, who approach infrastructure as code, who automate relentlessly, and who prioritize reliability. The specific tools are just implementation details.Stop chasing the perfect resume match. Start looking for the perfect mindset match instead.Your infrastructure (and your hiring timeline) will thank you.

🔥 ¿Realmente buscan talento o solo juegan con los candidatos?Después de varios procesos de selección, entrevistas y pruebas técnicas, quiero hablar de algo que, aunque todos sabemos que pasa, parece que nadie quiere decirlo en voz alta.✅ El guion siempre es el mismo:🔹 “¡Nos urge cerrar la vacante!”🔹 “Tu perfil es justo lo que buscamos.”🔹 “El proceso será rápido.”Te emocionas, te preparas, pasas entrevistas y pruebas técnicas (a veces largas y no pagadas)… y luego viene el infame silencio:❌ Correos sin responder.❌ Visto en WhatsApp.❌ Llamadas ignoradas.Y si logras que te respondan, siempre es la misma historia:🔸 “El cliente aún no decide.” (pero siguen entrevistando más gente)🔸 “El cliente canceló la vacante.” (pero sigue publicada una y otra vez)🔸 “Tu perfil es excelente, pero queremos evaluar más opciones.” (traducción: quieren pagar menos)🔸 “Estamos esperando aprobación.” (y seis meses después, la misma vacante sigue publicada)💼 Algunas verdades incómodas:📌 Piden 10 años de experiencia en tecnologías que existen hace 5.📌 Vacantes “urgentes” que terminan en procesos eternos o que mágicamente desaparecen.📌 Exigen un perfil Full Stack, pero con responsabilidades de DevOps, QA, SysAdmin y hasta Scrum Master, por un sueldo que apenas supera al de un becario.📌 Múltiples entrevistas, pruebas técnicas absurdas y exámenes interminables, solo para que al final elijan a alguien más barato o el proceso se cancele sin ninguna explicación.📌 “Buscamos el match perfecto”, pero cuando el candidato pide un sueldo acorde a su experiencia, mágicamente el presupuesto se reduce.📌 Piden honestidad en los CVs, pero no dan feedback, no responden mensajes y dejan a los candidatos en el limbo.💡 Entonces, ¿falta talento o falta estrategia en el reclutamiento?Se habla de escasez de talento, pero lo que realmente hay es:🚩 Procesos de selección mal estructurados.🚩 Expectativas irreales y sueldos que no corresponden con la experiencia requerida.🚩 Falta de compromiso con los candidatos.💼 A los reclutadores y headhunters:Si una vacante sigue abierta durante meses o años, tal vez el problema no es el candidato, sino su proceso de selección.Si ya entrevistaron a alguien y no lo seleccionaron, tengan la decencia de darle un cierre honesto en lugar de ignorarlo.No jueguen con el tiempo ni las esperanzas de las personas.📢 Candidatos, ¿les ha pasado? ¿Qué es lo más absurdo 🚀 Lift Others, Rise Together! 🤝🌱 Life is unpredictable, and the person struggling today might be the one hiring you tomorrow💯Unemployment is not just a status—it’s a tough phase filled with uncertainty, self-doubt, and endless job applications. 🌱 Both freshers, experienced professionals, and job changers face struggles that often go unnoticed:💼 Freshers:🔹 Applying to hundreds of jobs, only to be rejected for “lack of experience.”🔹 Struggling to get a response despite having the skills.🔹 Facing interviews where experience is valued more than potential.🎯 Experienced Professionals:🔹 Laid off unexpectedly, forced to start from scratch.🔹 Facing rejections due to “overqualification” or career gaps.🔹 Trying to switch industries but getting stuck in the experience trap.🔄 Job Changers:🔹 Stuck in toxic workplaces but afraid of instability.🔹 Wanting career growth but struggling to find better opportunities.🔹 Finding it hard to convince recruiters about domain changes.💡 What can we do?✅ Accept connection requests from job seekers—they are trying to expand their network, not spam.✅ Refer deserving candidates—a small effort from you can change their life.✅ Share job openings—someone in your network might be the perfect fit.✅ Offer guidance—a simple conversation can boost their confidence.🔄 If you’re hiring, drop a comment below! Dear recruiters, stop looking for candidates with 100% JD match.If someone matches your entire DevOps job description, you're chasing unicorns.Think about it.When you require 10+ years of Kubernetes (a technology from 2014), mastery of 3 different CI/CD tools, 4 logging/monitoring tools, 3 scripting language and expert-level knowledge across AWS, Azure, AND GCP... you're not describing a real candidate.You're describing a fantasy.And what happens when you actually find this rare specimen?They'll probably get bored and leave.The best DevOps engineers I've ever worked with weren't the ones who checked every technical box on day one. They were the ones who:- Demonstrated exceptional problem-solving skills- Had a genuine passion for automating everything- Possessed a "never stop learning" mindset- Understood that reliability matters more than fancy techMost skills in the DevOps world can be learned within weeks by someone with the right foundation.Hire engineers who meet 70-80% of your technical requirements but bring the right mindset.Focus on finding candidates who understand systems thinking, who approach infrastructure as code, who automate relentlessly, and who prioritize reliability. The specific tools are just implementation details.Stop chasing the perfect resume match. Start looking for the perfect mindset match instead.Your infrastructure (and your hiring timeline) will thank you.

🔥 ¿Realmente buscan talento o solo juegan con los candidatos?Después de varios procesos de selección, entrevistas y pruebas técnicas, quiero hablar de algo que, aunque todos sabemos que pasa, parece que nadie quiere decirlo en voz alta.✅ El guion siempre es el mismo:🔹 “¡Nos urge cerrar la vacante!”🔹 “Tu perfil es justo lo que buscamos.”🔹 “El proceso será rápido.”Te emocionas, te preparas, pasas entrevistas y pruebas técnicas (a veces largas y no pagadas)… y luego viene el infame silencio:❌ Correos sin responder.❌ Visto en WhatsApp.❌ Llamadas ignoradas.Y si logras que te respondan, siempre es la misma historia:🔸 “El cliente aún no decide.” (pero siguen entrevistando más gente)🔸 “El cliente canceló la vacante.” (pero sigue publicada una y otra vez)🔸 “Tu perfil es excelente, pero queremos evaluar más opciones.” (traducción: quieren pagar menos)🔸 “Estamos esperando aprobación.” (y seis meses después, la misma vacante sigue publicada)💼 Algunas verdades incómodas:📌 Piden 10 años de experiencia en tecnologías que existen hace 5.📌 Vacantes “urgentes” que terminan en procesos eternos o que mágicamente desaparecen.📌 Exigen un perfil Full Stack, pero con responsabilidades de DevOps, QA, SysAdmin y hasta Scrum Master, por un sueldo que apenas supera al de un becario.📌 Múltiples entrevistas, pruebas técnicas absurdas y exámenes interminables, solo para que al final elijan a alguien más barato o el proceso se cancele sin ninguna explicación.📌 “Buscamos el match perfecto”, pero cuando el candidato pide un sueldo acorde a su experiencia, mágicamente el presupuesto se reduce.📌 Piden honestidad en los CVs, pero no dan feedback, no responden mensajes y dejan a los candidatos en el limbo.💡 Entonces, ¿falta talento o falta estrategia en el reclutamiento?Se habla de escasez de talento, pero lo que realmente hay es:🚩 Procesos de selección mal estructurados.🚩 Expectativas irreales y sueldos que no corresponden con la experiencia requerida.🚩 Falta de compromiso con los candidatos.💼 A los reclutadores y headhunters:Si una vacante sigue abierta durante meses o años, tal vez el problema no es el candidato, sino su proceso de selección.Si ya entrevistaron a alguien y no lo seleccionaron, tengan la decencia de darle un cierre honesto en lugar de ignorarlo.No jueguen con el tiempo ni las esperanzas de las personas.📢 Candidatos, ¿les ha pasado? ¿Qué es lo más absurdo que les han dicho en un proceso de selección?Reclutadores, si creen que estoy equivocado, los leo en los comentarios. 👇hashtag#Reclutamiento hashtag#Hiring hashtag#RRHH hashtag#Respeto hashtag#Trabajo hashtag#TalentAcquisition hashtag#Candidatos hashtag#Transparencia hashtag#JusticiaLaboral hashtag#Recruitment hashtag#HiringProcess hashtag#TalentHunting hashtag#HRInsights hashtag#Headhunting hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#RecruitingFail hashtag#TrabajoDigno hashtag#JusticiaSalarial hashtag#WorkCulture hashtag#TrabajoRemoto hashtag#JobSeekers hashtag#Employment hashtag#CareerOpportunities hashtag#CandidateExperience hashtag#NoMásGhosting hashtag#FeedbackLaboral hashtag#RespetoLaboral hashtag#HiringTransparency

🚀 Lift Others, Rise Together! 🤝🌱 Life is unpredictable, and the person struggling today might be the one hiring you tomorrow💯Unemployment is not just a status—it’s a tough phase filled with uncertainty, self-doubt, and endless job applications. 🌱 Both freshers, experienced professionals, and job changers face struggles that often go unnoticed:💼 Freshers:🔹 Applying to hundreds of jobs, only to be rejected for “lack of experience.”🔹 Struggling to get a response despite having the skills.🔹 Facing interviews where experience is valued more than potential.🎯 Experienced Professionals:🔹 Laid off unexpectedly, forced to start from scratch.🔹 Facing rejections due to “overqualification” or career gaps.🔹 Trying to switch industries but getting stuck in the experience trap.🔄 Job Changers:🔹 Stuck in toxic workplaces but afraid of instability.🔹 Wanting career growth but struggling to find better opportunities.🔹 Finding it hard to convince recruiters about domain changes.💡 What can we do?✅ Accept connection requests from job seekers—they are trying to expand their network, not spam.✅ Refer deserving candidates—a small effort from you can change their life.✅ Share job openings—someone in your network might be the perfect fit.✅ Offer guidance—a simple conversation can boost their confidence.🔄 If you’re hiring, drop a comment below! Dear recruiters, stop looking for candidates with 100% JD match.If someone matches your entire DevOps job description, you're chasing unicorns.Think about it.When you require 10+ years of Kubernetes (a technology from 2014), mastery of 3 different CI/CD tools, 4 logging/monitoring tools, 3 scripting language and expert-level knowledge across AWS, Azure, AND GCP... you're not describing a real candidate.You're describing a fantasy.And what happens when you actually find this rare specimen?They'll probably get bored and leave.The best DevOps engineers I've ever worked with weren't the ones who checked every technical box on day one. They were the ones who:- Demonstrated exceptional problem-solving skills- Had a genuine passion for automating everything- Possessed a "never stop learning" mindset- Understood that reliability matters more than fancy techMost skills in the DevOps world can be learned within weeks by someone with the right foundation.Hire engineers who meet 70-80% of your technical requirements but bring the right mindset.Focus on finding candidates who understand systems thinking, who approach infrastructure as code, who automate relentlessly, and who prioritize reliability. The specific tools are just implementation details.Stop chasing the perfect resume match. Start looking for the perfect mindset match instead.Your infrastructure (and your hiring timeline) will thank you.

🔥 ¿Realmente buscan talento o solo juegan con los candidatos?Después de varios procesos de selección, entrevistas y pruebas técnicas, quiero hablar de algo que, aunque todos sabemos que pasa, parece que nadie quiere decirlo en voz alta.✅ El guion siempre es el mismo:🔹 “¡Nos urge cerrar la vacante!”🔹 “Tu perfil es justo lo que buscamos.”🔹 “El proceso será rápido.”Te emocionas, te preparas, pasas entrevistas y pruebas técnicas (a veces largas y no pagadas)… y luego viene el infame silencio:❌ Correos sin responder.❌ Visto en WhatsApp.❌ Llamadas ignoradas.Y si logras que te respondan, siempre es la misma historia:🔸 “El cliente aún no decide.” (pero siguen entrevistando más gente)🔸 “El cliente canceló la vacante.” (pero sigue publicada una y otra vez)🔸 “Tu perfil es excelente, pero queremos evaluar más opciones.” (traducción: quieren pagar menos)🔸 “Estamos esperando aprobación.” (y seis meses después, la misma vacante sigue publicada)💼 Algunas verdades incómodas:📌 Piden 10 años de experiencia en tecnologías que existen hace 5.📌 Vacantes “urgentes” que terminan en procesos eternos o que mágicamente desaparecen.📌 Exigen un perfil Full Stack, pero con responsabilidades de DevOps, QA, SysAdmin y hasta Scrum Master, por un sueldo que apenas supera al de un becario.📌 Múltiples entrevistas, pruebas técnicas absurdas y exámenes interminables, solo para que al final elijan a alguien más barato o el proceso se cancele sin ninguna explicación.📌 “Buscamos el match perfecto”, pero cuando el candidato pide un sueldo acorde a su experiencia, mágicamente el presupuesto se reduce.📌 Piden honestidad en los CVs, pero no dan feedback, no responden mensajes y dejan a los candidatos en el limbo.💡 Entonces, ¿falta talento o falta estrategia en el reclutamiento?Se habla de escasez de talento, pero lo que realmente hay es:🚩 Procesos de selección mal estructurados.🚩 Expectativas irreales y sueldos que no corresponden con la experiencia requerida.🚩 Falta de compromiso con los candidatos.💼 A los reclutadores y headhunters:Si una vacante sigue abierta durante meses o años, tal vez el problema no es el candidato, sino su proceso de selección.Si ya entrevistaron a alguien y no lo seleccionaron, tengan la decencia de darle un cierre honesto en lugar de ignorarlo.No jueguen con el tiempo ni las esperanzas de las personas.📢 Candidatos, ¿les ha pasado? ¿Qué es lo más absurdo que les han dicho en un proceso de selección?Reclutadores, si creen que estoy equivocado, los leo en los comentarios. 👇hashtag#Reclutamiento hashtag#Hiring hashtag#RRHH hashtag#Respeto hashtag#Trabajo 🚀 Lift Others, Rise Together! 🤝🌱 Life is unpredictable, and the person struggling today might be the one hiring you tomorrow💯Unemployment is not just a status—it’s a tough phase filled with uncertainty, self-doubt, and endless job applications. 🌱 Both freshers, experienced professionals, and job changers face struggles that often go unnoticed:💼 Freshers:🔹 Applying to hundreds of jobs, only to be rejected for “lack of experience.”🔹 Struggling to get a response despite having the skills.🔹 Facing interviews where experience is valued more than potential.🎯 Experienced Professionals:🔹 Laid off unexpectedly, forced to start from scratch.🔹 Facing rejections due to “overqualification” or career gaps.🔹 Trying to switch industries but getting stuck in the experience trap.🔄 Job Changers:🔹 Stuck in toxic workplaces but afraid of instability.🔹 Wanting career growth but struggling to find better opportunities.🔹 Finding it hard to convince recruiters about domain changes.💡 What can we do?✅ Accept connection requests from job seekers—they are trying to expand their network, not spam.✅ Refer deserving candidates—a small effort from you can change their life.✅ Share job openings—someone in your network might be the perfect fit.✅ Offer guidance—a simple conversation can boost their confidence.🔄 If you’re hiring, drop a comment below! You don’t need to know everything about AWS, but you should know this.Many people get stuck when starting with AWS because they think they need to master all 200+ services before deploying something to production.The truth? Most web applications use fewer than 10 services.If I had to relearn AWS in a more productive way—beyond just reading the docs and taking AWS courses—I would focus on these:✅ EC2 (Elastic Compute Cloud) – Scalable virtual machines that provide computing power to run applications, offering flexibility in instance types, storage, and networking.✅ ECS (Elastic Container Service) with Fargate – A managed container orchestration service that allows you to run Docker containers without provisioning or managing servers, simplifying deployment and scaling.✅ S3 (Simple Storage Service) – Highly durable and scalable object storage designed for storing and retrieving files, backups, and static content, with built-in security and lifecycle policies.✅ RDS (Relational Database Service) / DynamoDB – RDS provides managed relational databases (MySQL, PostgreSQL, SQL Server, etc.), while DynamoDB is a fully managed NoSQL database optimized for high-performance and scalable applications.✅ Lambda – A serverless compute service that runs code in response to events (like API requests or file uploads) without the need to manage infrastructure, charging only for execution time.✅ API Gateway – A fully managed service that enables developers to create, deploy, and secure APIs at scale, integrating seamlessly with Lambda, EC2, and other AWS services.✅ CloudWatch – A monitoring and observability service that collects logs, metrics, and events from AWS resources, enabling real-time insights, alerting, and troubleshooting.✅ IAM (Identity and Access Management) – AWS’s security framework for managing users, roles, and permissions to control access to AWS resources. Misconfigurations here can lead to serious security risks.✅ SNS (Simple Notification Service) / SQS (Simple Queue Service) – SNS is a pub/sub messaging service for sending notifications, while SQS provides message queuing for decoupling and scaling microservices, distributed systems, and serverless applications.Master these, and you’ll solve 90% of AWS-related problems without needing to memorize everything.AWS is huge, but you don’t need to know it all to be effective. Focus on what matters.hashtag#AWS hashtag#CloudComputing hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#DevOps hashtag#BackendDevelopment hashtag#Cloud hashtag#AWSCommunity hashtag#CloudEngineer hashtag#AWSJobs hashtag#TechCareer hashtag#AWSLambda hashtag#AmazonWebServices hashtag#Hiring hashtag#OpenToWork hashtag#SoftwareDeveloper hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#dotnet hashtag#backend

Dear recruiters, stop looking for candidates with 100% JD match.If someone matches your entire DevOps job description, you're chasing unicorns.Think about it.When you require 10+ years of Kubernetes (a technology from 2014), mastery of 3 different CI/CD tools, 4 logging/monitoring tools, 3 scripting language and expert-level knowledge across AWS, Azure, AND GCP... you're not describing a real candidate.You're describing a fantasy.And what happens when you actually find this rare specimen?They'll probably get bored and leave.The best DevOps engineers I've ever worked with weren't the ones who checked every technical box on day one. They were the ones who:- Demonstrated exceptional problem-solving skills- Had a genuine passion for automating everything- Possessed a "never stop learning" mindset- Understood that reliability matters more than fancy techMost skills in the DevOps world can be learned within weeks by someone with the right foundation.Hire engineers who meet 70-80% of your technical requirements but bring the right mindset.Focus on finding candidates who understand systems thinking, who approach infrastructure as code, who automate relentlessly, and who prioritize reliability. The specific tools are just implementation details.Stop chasing the perfect resume match. Start looking for the perfect mindset match instead.Your infrastructure (and your hiring timeline) will thank you.

🔥 ¿Realmente buscan talento o solo juegan con los candidatos?Después de varios procesos de selección, entrevistas y pruebas técnicas, quiero hablar de algo que, aunque todos sabemos que pasa, parece que nadie quiere decirlo en voz alta.✅ El guion siempre es el mismo:🔹 “¡Nos urge cerrar la vacante!”🔹 “Tu perfil es justo lo que buscamos.”🔹 “El proceso será rápido.”Te emocionas, te preparas, pasas entrevistas y pruebas técnicas (a veces largas y no pagadas)… y luego viene el infame silencio:❌ Correos sin responder.❌ Visto en WhatsApp.❌ Llamadas ignoradas.Y si logras que te respondan, siempre es la misma historia:🔸 “El cliente aún no decide.” (pero siguen entrevistando más gente)🔸 “El cliente canceló la vacante.” (pero sigue publicada una y otra vez)🔸 “Tu perfil es excelente, pero queremos evaluar más opciones.” (traducción: quieren pagar menos)🔸 “Estamos esperando aprobación.” (y seis meses después, la misma vacante sigue publicada)💼 Algunas verdades incómodas:📌 Piden 10 años de experiencia en tecnologías que existen hace 5.📌 Vacantes “urgentes” que terminan en procesos eternos o que mágicamente desaparecen.📌 Exigen un perfil Full Stack, pero con responsabilidades de DevOps, QA, SysAdmin y hasta Scrum Master, por un sueldo que apenas supera al de un becario.📌 Múltiples entrevistas, pruebas técnicas absurdas y exámenes interminables, solo para que al final elijan a alguien más barato o el proceso se cancele sin ninguna explicación.📌 “Buscamos el match perfecto”, pero cuando el candidato pide un sueldo acorde a su experiencia, mágicamente el presupuesto se reduce.📌 Piden honestidad en los CVs, pero no dan feedback, no responden mensajes y dejan a los candidatos en el limbo.💡 Entonces, ¿falta talento o falta estrategia en el reclutamiento?Se habla de escasez de talento, pero lo que realmente hay es:🚩 Procesos de selección mal estructurados.🚩 Expectativas irreales y sueldos que no corresponden con la experiencia requerida.🚩 Falta de compromiso con los candidatos.💼 A los reclutadores y headhunters:Si una vacante sigue abierta durante meses o años, tal vez el problema no es el candidato, sino su proceso de selección.Si ya entrevistaron a alguien y no lo seleccionaron, tengan la decencia de darle un cierre honesto en lugar de ignorarlo.No jueguen con el tiempo ni las esperanzas de las personas.📢 Candidatos, ¿les ha pasado? ¿Qué es lo más absurdo que les han dicho en un proceso de selección?Reclutadores, si creen que estoy equivocado, los leo en los comentarios. 👇hashtag#Reclutamiento hashtag#Hiring hashtag#RRHH hashtag#Respeto hashtag#Trabajo 🚀 Lift Others, Rise Together! 🤝🌱 Life is unpredictable, and the person struggling today might be the one hiring you tomorrow💯Unemployment is not just a status—it’s a tough phase filled with uncertainty, self-doubt, and endless job applications. 🌱 Both freshers, experienced professionals, and job changers face struggles that often go unnoticed:💼 Freshers:🔹 Applying to hundreds of jobs, only to be rejected for “lack of experience.”🔹 Struggling to get a response despite having the skills.🔹 Facing interviews where experience is valued more than potential.🎯 Experienced Professionals:🔹 Laid off unexpectedly, forced to start from scratch.🔹 Facing rejections due to “overqualification” or career gaps.🔹 Trying to switch industries but getting stuck in the experience trap.🔄 Job Changers:🔹 Stuck in toxic workplaces but afraid of instability.🔹 Wanting career growth but struggling to find better opportunities.🔹 Finding it hard to convince recruiters about domain changes.💡 What can we do?✅ Accept connection requests from job seekers—they are trying to expand their network, not spam.✅ Refer deserving candidates—a small effort from you can change their life.✅ Share job openings—someone in your network might be the perfect fit.✅ Offer guidance—a simple conversation can boost their confidence.🔄 If you’re hiring, drop a comment below! You don’t need to know everything about AWS, but you should know this.Many people get stuck when starting with AWS because they think they need to master all 200+ services before deploying something to production.The truth? Most web applications use fewer than 10 services.If I had to relearn AWS in a more productive way—beyond just reading the docs and taking AWS courses—I would focus on these:✅ EC2 (Elastic Compute Cloud) – Scalable virtual machines that provide computing power to run applications, offering flexibility in instance types, storage, and networking.✅ ECS (Elastic Container Service) with Fargate – A managed container orchestration service that allows you to run Docker containers without provisioning or managing servers, simplifying deployment and scaling.✅ S3 (Simple Storage Service) – Highly durable and scalable object storage designed for storing and retrieving files, backups, and static content, with built-in security and lifecycle policies.✅ RDS (Relational Database Service) / DynamoDB – RDS provides managed relational databases (MySQL, PostgreSQL, SQL Server, etc.), while DynamoDB is a fully managed NoSQL database optimized for high-performance and scalable applications.✅ Lambda – A serverless compute service that runs code in response to events (like API requests or file uploads) without the need to manage infrastructure, charging only for execution time.✅ API Gateway – A fully managed service that enables developers to create, deploy, and secure APIs at scale, integrating seamlessly with Lambda, EC2, and other AWS services.✅ CloudWatch – A monitoring and observability service that collects logs, metrics, and events from AWS resources, enabling real-time insights, alerting, and troubleshooting.✅ IAM (Identity and Access Management) – AWS’s security framework for managing users, roles, and permissions to control access to AWS resources. Misconfigurations here can lead to serious security risks.✅ SNS (Simple Notification Service) / SQS (Simple Queue Service) – SNS is a pub/sub messaging service for sending notifications, while SQS provides message queuing for decoupling and scaling microservices, distributed systems, and serverless applications.Master these, and you’ll solve 90% of AWS-related problems without needing to memorize everything.AWS is huge, but you don’t need to know it all to be effective. Dear recruiters, stop looking for candidates with 100% JD match.If someone matches your entire DevOps job description, you're chasing unicorns.Think about it.When you require 10+ years of Kubernetes (a technology from 2014), mastery of 3 different CI/CD tools, 4 logging/monitoring tools, 3 scripting language and expert-level knowledge across AWS, Azure, AND GCP... you're not describing a real candidate.You're describing a fantasy.And what happens when you actually find this rare specimen?They'll probably get bored and leave.The best DevOps engineers I've ever worked with weren't the ones who checked every technical box on day one. They were the ones who:- Demonstrated exceptional problem-solving skills- Had a genuine passion for automating everything- Possessed a "never stop learning" mindset- Understood that reliability matters more than fancy techMost skills in the DevOps world can be learned within weeks by someone with the right foundation.Hire engineers who meet 70-80% of your technical requirements but bring the right mindset.Focus on finding candidates who understand systems thinking, who approach infrastructure as code, who automate relentlessly, and who prioritize reliability. The specific tools are just implementation details.Stop chasing the perfect resume match. Start looking for the perfect mindset match instead.Your infrastructure (and your hiring timeline) will thank you.

🔥 ¿Realmente buscan talento o solo juegan con los candidatos?Después de varios procesos de selección, entrevistas y pruebas técnicas, quiero hablar de algo que, aunque todos sabemos que pasa, parece que nadie quiere decirlo en voz alta.✅ El guion siempre es el mismo:🔹 “¡Nos urge cerrar la vacante!”🔹 “Tu perfil es justo lo que buscamos.”🔹 “El proceso será rápido.”Te emocionas, te preparas, pasas entrevistas y pruebas técnicas (a veces largas y no pagadas)… y luego viene el infame silencio:❌ Correos sin responder.❌ Visto en WhatsApp.❌ Llamadas ignoradas.Y si logras que te respondan, siempre es la misma historia:🔸 “El cliente aún no decide.” (pero siguen entrevistando más gente)🔸 “El cliente canceló la vacante.” (pero sigue publicada una y otra vez)🔸 “Tu perfil es excelente, pero queremos evaluar más opciones.” (traducción: quieren pagar menos)🔸 “Estamos esperando aprobación.” (y seis meses después, la misma vacante sigue publicada)💼 Algunas verdades incómodas:📌 Piden 10 años de experiencia en tecnologías que existen hace 5.📌 Vacantes “urgentes” que terminan en procesos eternos o que mágicamente desaparecen.📌 Exigen un perfil Full Stack, pero con responsabilidades de DevOps, QA, SysAdmin y hasta Scrum Master, por un sueldo que apenas supera al de un becario.📌 Múltiples entrevistas, pruebas técnicas absurdas y exámenes interminables, solo para que al final elijan a alguien más barato o el proceso se cancele sin ninguna explicación.📌 “Buscamos el match perfecto”, pero cuando el candidato pide un sueldo acorde a su experiencia, mágicamente el presupuesto se reduce.📌 Piden honestidad en los CVs, pero no dan feedback, no responden mensajes y dejan a los candidatos en el limbo.💡 Entonces, ¿falta talento o falta estrategia en el reclutamiento?Se habla de escasez de talento, pero lo que realmente hay es:🚩 Procesos de selección mal estructurados.🚩 Expectativas irreales y sueldos que no corresponden con la experiencia requerida.🚩 Falta de compromiso con los candidatos.💼 A los reclutadores y headhunters:Si una vacante sigue abierta durante meses o años, tal vez el problema no es el candidato, sino su proceso de selección.Si ya entrevistaron a alguien y no lo seleccionaron, tengan la decencia de darle un cierre honesto en lugar de ignorarlo.No jueguen con el tiempo ni las esperanzas de las personas.📢 Candidatos, ¿les ha pasado? ¿Qué es lo más absurdo que les han dicho en un proceso de selección?Reclutadores, si creen que estoy equivocado, los leo en los comentarios. 👇hashtag#Reclutamiento hashtag#Hiring hashtag#RRHH hashtag#Respeto hashtag#Trabajo hashtag#TalentAcquisition hashtag#Candidatos hashtag#Transparencia hashtag#JusticiaLaboral hashtag#Recruitment hashtag#HiringProcess hashtag#TalentHunting hashtag#HRInsights hashtag#Headhunting hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#RecruitingFail hashtag#TrabajoDigno hashtag#JusticiaSalarial hashtag#WorkCulture hashtag#TrabajoRemoto hashtag#JobSeekers hashtag#Employment hashtag#CareerOpportunities hashtag#CandidateExperience hashtag#NoMásGhosting hashtag#FeedbackLaboral hashtag#RespetoLaboral hashtag#HiringTransparency

🚀 Lift Others, Rise Together! 🤝🌱 Life is unpredictable, and the person struggling today might be the one hiring you tomorrow💯Unemployment is not just a status—it’s a tough phase filled with uncertainty, self-doubt, and endless job applications. 🌱 Both freshers, experienced professionals, and job changers face struggles that often go unnoticed:💼 Freshers:🔹 Applying to hundreds of jobs, only to be rejected for “lack of experience.”🔹 Struggling to get a response despite having the skills.🔹 Facing interviews where experience is valued more than potential.🎯 Experienced Professionals:🔹 Laid off unexpectedly, forced to start from scratch.🔹 Facing rejections due to “overqualification” or career gaps.🔹 Trying to switch industries but getting stuck in the experience trap.🔄 Job Changers:🔹 Stuck in toxic workplaces but afraid of instability.🔹 Wanting career growth but struggling to find better opportunities.🔹 Finding it hard to convince recruiters about domain changes.💡 What can we do?✅ Accept connection requests from job seekers—they are trying to expand their network, not spam.✅ Refer deserving candidates—a small effort from you can change their life.✅ Share job openings—someone in your network might be the perfect fit.✅ Offer guidance—a simple conversation can boost their confidence.🔄 If you’re hiring, drop a comment below! You don’t need to know everything about AWS, but you should know this.Many people get stuck when starting with AWS because they think they need to master all 200+ services before deploying something to production.The truth? Most web applications use fewer than 10 services.If I had to relearn AWS in a more productive way—beyond just reading the docs and taking AWS courses—I would focus on these:✅ EC2 (Elastic Compute Cloud) – Scalable virtual machines that provide computing power to run applications, offering flexibility in instance types, storage, and networking.✅ ECS (Elastic Container Service) with Fargate – A managed container orchestration service that allows you to run Docker containers without provisioning or managing servers, simplifying deployment and scaling.✅ S3 (Simple Storage Service) – Highly durable and scalable object storage designed for storing and retrieving files, backups, and static content, with built-in security and lifecycle policies.✅ RDS (Relational Database Service) / DynamoDB – RDS provides managed relational databases (MySQL, PostgreSQL, SQL Server, etc.), while DynamoDB is a fully managed NoSQL database optimized for high-performance and scalable applications.✅ Lambda – A serverless compute service that runs code in response to events (like API requests or file uploads) without the need to manage infrastructure, charging only for execution time.✅ API Gateway – A fully managed service that enables developers to create, deploy, and secure APIs at scale, integrating seamlessly with Lambda, EC2, and other AWS services.✅ CloudWatch – A monitoring and observability service that collects logs, metrics, and events from AWS resources, enabling real-time insights, alerting, and troubleshooting.✅ IAM (Identity and Access Management) – AWS’s security framework for managing users, roles, and permissions to control access to AWS resources. Misconfigurations here can lead to serious security risks.✅ SNS (Simple Notification Service) / SQS (Simple Queue Service) – SNS is a pub/sub messaging service for sending notifications, while SQS provides message queuing for decoupling and scaling microservices, distributed systems, and serverless applications.Master these, and you’ll solve 90% of AWS-related problems without needing to memorize everything.AWS is huge, but you don’t need to know it all to be effective. Focus on what matters.hashtag#AWS hashtag#CloudComputing hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#DevOps hashtag#BackendDevelopment hashtag#Cloud hashtag#AWSCommunity hashtag#CloudEngineer hashtag#AWSJobs hashtag#TechCareer hashtag#AWSLambda hashtag#AmazonWebServices hashtag#Hiring hashtag#OpenToWork hashtag#SoftwareDeveloper hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#dotnet hashtag#backend

Dear recruiters, stop looking for candidates with 100% JD match.If someone matches your entire DevOps job description, you're chasing unicorns.Think about it.When you require 10+ years of Kubernetes (a technology from 2014), mastery of 3 different CI/CD tools, 4 logging/monitoring tools, 3 scripting language and expert-level knowledge across AWS, Azure, AND GCP... you're not describing a real candidate.You're describing a fantasy.And what happens when you actually find this rare specimen?They'll probably get bored and leave.The best DevOps engineers I've ever worked with weren't the ones who checked every technical box on day one. They were the ones who:- Demonstrated exceptional problem-solving skills- Had a genuine passion for automating everything- Possessed a "never stop learning" mindset- Understood that reliability matters more than fancy techMost skills in the DevOps world can be learned within weeks by someone with the right foundation.Hire engineers who meet 70-80% of your technical requirements but bring the right mindset.Focus on finding candidates who understand systems thinking, who approach infrastructure as code, who automate relentlessly, and who prioritize reliability. The specific tools are just implementation details.Stop chasing the perfect resume match. Start looking for the perfect mindset match instead.Your infrastructure (and your hiring timeline) will thank you.

🔥 ¿Realmente buscan talento o solo juegan con los candidatos?Después de varios procesos de selección, entrevistas y pruebas técnicas, quiero hablar de algo que, aunque todos sabemos que pasa, parece que nadie quiere decirlo en voz alta.✅ El guion siempre es el mismo:🔹 “¡Nos urge cerrar la vacante!”🔹 “Tu perfil es justo lo que buscamos.”🔹 “El proceso será rápido.”Te emocionas, te preparas, pasas entrevistas y pruebas técnicas (a veces largas y no pagadas)… y luego viene el infame silencio:❌ Correos sin responder.❌ Visto en WhatsApp.❌ Llamadas ignoradas.Y si logras que te respondan, siempre es la misma historia:🔸 “El cliente aún no decide.” (pero siguen entrevistando más gente)🔸 “El cliente canceló la vacante.” (pero sigue publicada una y otra vez)🔸 “Tu perfil es excelente, pero queremos evaluar más opciones.” (traducción: quieren pagar menos)🔸 “Estamos esperando aprobación.” (y seis meses después, la misma vacante sigue publicada)💼 Algunas verdades incómodas:📌 Piden 10 años de experiencia en tecnologías que existen hace 5.📌 Vacantes “urgentes” que terminan en procesos eternos o que mágicamente desaparecen.📌 Exigen un perfil Full Stack, pero con responsabilidades de DevOps, QA, SysAdmin y hasta Scrum Master, por un sueldo que apenas supera al de un becario.📌 Múltiples entrevistas, pruebas técnicas absurdas y exámenes interminables, solo para que al final elijan a alguien más barato o el proceso se cancele sin ninguna explicación.📌 “Buscamos el match perfecto”, pero cuando el candidato pide un sueldo acorde a su experiencia, mágicamente el presupuesto se reduce.📌 Piden honestidad en los CVs, pero no dan feedback, no responden mensajes y dejan a los candidatos en el limbo.💡 Entonces, ¿falta talento o falta estrategia en el reclutamiento?Se habla de escasez de talento, pero lo que realmente hay es:🚩 Procesos de selección mal estructurados.🚩 Expectativas irreales y sueldos que no corresponden con la experiencia requerida.🚩 Falta de compromiso con los candidatos.💼 A los reclutadores y headhunters:Si una vacante sigue abierta durante meses o años, tal vez el problema no es el candidato, sino su proceso de selección.Si ya entrevistaron a alguien y no lo seleccionaron, tengan la decencia de darle un cierre honesto en lugar de ignorarlo.No jueguen con el tiempo ni las esperanzas de las personas.📢 Candidatos, ¿les ha pasado? ¿Qué es lo más absurdo que les han dicho en un proceso de selección?Reclutadores, si creen que estoy equivocado, los leo en los comentarios. 👇hashtag#Reclutamiento hashtag#Hiring hashtag#RRHH hashtag#Respeto hashtag#Trabajo 🚀 Lift Others, Rise Together! 🤝🌱 Life is unpredictable, and the person struggling today might be the one hiring you tomorrow💯Unemployment is not just a status—it’s a tough phase filled with uncertainty, self-doubt, and endless job applications. 🌱 Both freshers, experienced professionals, and job changers face struggles that often go unnoticed:💼 Freshers:🔹 Applying to hundreds of jobs, only to be rejected for “lack of experience.”🔹 Struggling to get a response despite having the skills.🔹 Facing interviews where experience is valued more than potential.🎯 Experienced Professionals:🔹 Laid off unexpectedly, forced to start from scratch.🔹 Facing rejections due to “overqualification” or career gaps.🔹 Trying to switch industries but getting stuck in the experience trap.🔄 Job Changers:🔹 Stuck in toxic workplaces but afraid of instability.🔹 Wanting career growth but struggling to find better opportunities.🔹 Finding it hard to convince recruiters about domain changes.💡 What can we do?✅ Accept connection requests from job seekers—they are trying to expand their network, not spam.✅ Refer deserving candidates—a small effort from you can change their life.✅ Share job openings—someone in your network might be the perfect fit.✅ Offer guidance—a simple conversation can boost their confidence.🔄 If you’re hiring, drop a comment below! You don’t need to know everything about AWS, but you should know this.Many people get stuck when starting with AWS because they think they need to master all 200+ services before deploying something to production.The truth? Most web applications use fewer than 10 services.If I had to relearn AWS in a more productive way—beyond just reading the docs and taking AWS courses—I would focus on these:✅ EC2 (Elastic Compute Cloud) – Scalable virtual machines that provide computing power to run applications, offering flexibility in instance types, storage, and networking.✅ ECS (Elastic Container Service) with Fargate – A managed container orchestration service that allows you to run Docker containers without provisioning or managing servers, simplifying deployment and scaling.✅ S3 (Simple Storage Service) – Highly durable and scalable object storage designed for storing and retrieving files, backups, and static content, with built-in security and lifecycle policies.✅ RDS (Relational Database Service) / DynamoDB – RDS provides managed relational databases (MySQL, PostgreSQL, SQL Server, etc.), while DynamoDB is a fully managed NoSQL database optimized for high-performance and scalable applications.✅ Lambda – A serverless compute service that runs code in response to events (like API requests or file uploads) without the need to manage infrastructure, charging only for execution time.✅ API Gateway – A fully managed service that enables developers to create, deploy, and secure APIs at scale, integrating seamlessly with Lambda, EC2, and other AWS services.✅ CloudWatch – A monitoring and observability service that collects logs, metrics, and events from AWS resources, enabling real-time insights, alerting, and troubleshooting.✅ IAM (Identity and Access Management) – AWS’s security framework for managing users, roles, and permissions to control access to AWS resources. Misconfigurations here can lead to serious security risks.✅ SNS (Simple Notification Service) / SQS (Simple Queue Service) – SNS is a pub/sub messaging service for sending notifications, while SQS provides message queuing for decoupling and scaling microservices, distributed systems, and serverless applications.Master these, and you’ll solve 90% of AWS-related problems without needing to memorize everything.AWS is huge, but you don’t need to know it all to be effective. Here’s why and how to stay ahead of the competition.🔥 Why It’s Getting Harder to Relocate✅ Market Saturation – More developers entering the field via bootcamps & self-learning. ✅ Remote Work Expansion – Companies prefer remote hires over relocation costs. ✅ Economic Uncertainty – Startups & mid-sized companies are tightening budgets. ✅ AI & No-Code Solutions – Reducing demand for traditional development tasks.🎯 How to Get Ahead & Land That Job1️⃣ 🚀 Specialize in High-Demand Skills🔹 Instead of being a generalist, go deep into Rust, Web3, AI integrations, or cybersecurity. 🔹 If you already know Laravel, Vue, Node, or React, position yourself as a Rust specialist to stand out.2️⃣ 📢 Build a Personal Brand🔹 Share insights, projects, and industry trends on LinkedIn & Twitter. 🔹 Write blog posts or even create video content on Rust, AI, or full-stack best practices.3️⃣ 🤝 Leverage Networking & Open Source🔹 Engage with Rust & Laravel communities (Discord, GitHub, LinkedIn groups). 🔹 Contribute to open-source projects—many companies hire directly from contributors!4️⃣ 📈 Stay Ahead with AI & Automation🔹 Learn how AI-driven DevOps & automation can boost productivity. 🔹 Companies love developers who understand AI-powered workflows.5️⃣ 🎯 Target the Right Companies🔹 Look for Rust-first startups, fintechs, AI-driven businesses, and blockchain firms. 🔹 Skip mass-market job boards—network directly with hiring managers & founders.🚀 The market is tough, but opportunities are still there for those who stand out. 💬 What’s your strategy for staying competitive in web development? Let’s discuss in the comments! 👇

Dear recruiters, stop looking for candidates with 100% JD match.If someone matches your entire DevOps job description, you're chasing unicorns.Think about it.When you require 10+ years of Kubernetes (a technology from 2014), mastery of 3 different CI/CD tools, 4 logging/monitoring tools, 3 scripting language and expert-level knowledge across AWS, Azure, AND GCP... you're not describing a real candidate.You're describing a fantasy.And what happens when you actually find this rare specimen?They'll probably get bored and leave.The best DevOps engineers I've ever worked with weren't the ones who checked every technical box on day one. They were the ones who:- Demonstrated exceptional problem-solving skills- Had a genuine passion for automating everything- Possessed a "never stop learning" mindset- Understood that reliability matters more than fancy techMost skills in the DevOps world can be learned within weeks by someone with the right foundation.Hire engineers who meet 70-80% of your technical requirements but bring the right mindset.Focus on finding candidates who understand systems thinking, who approach infrastructure as code, who automate relentlessly, and who prioritize reliability. The specific tools are just implementation details.Stop chasing the perfect resume match. Start looking for the perfect mindset match instead.Your infrastructure (and your hiring timeline) will thank you.

🔥 ¿Realmente buscan talento o solo juegan con los candidatos?Después de varios procesos de selección, entrevistas y pruebas técnicas, quiero hablar de algo que, aunque todos sabemos que pasa, parece que nadie quiere decirlo en voz alta.✅ El guion siempre es el mismo:🔹 “¡Nos urge cerrar la vacante!”🔹 “Tu perfil es justo lo que buscamos.”🔹 “El proceso será rápido.”Te emocionas, te preparas, pasas entrevistas y pruebas técnicas (a veces largas y no pagadas)… y luego viene el infame silencio:❌ Correos sin responder.❌ Visto en WhatsApp.❌ Llamadas ignoradas.Y si logras que te respondan, siempre es la misma historia:🔸 “El cliente aún no decide.” (pero siguen entrevistando más gente)🔸 “El cliente canceló la vacante.” (pero sigue publicada una y otra vez)🔸 “Tu perfil es excelente, pero queremos evaluar más opciones.” (traducción: quieren pagar menos)🔸 “Estamos esperando aprobación.” (y seis meses después, la misma vacante sigue publicada)💼 Algunas verdades incómodas:📌 Piden 10 años de experiencia en tecnologías que existen hace 5.📌 Vacantes “urgentes” que terminan en procesos eternos o que mágicamente desaparecen.📌 Exigen un perfil Full Stack, pero con responsabilidades de DevOps, QA, SysAdmin y hasta Scrum Master, por un sueldo que apenas supera al de un becario.📌 Múltiples entrevistas, pruebas técnicas absurdas y exámenes interminables, solo para que al final elijan a alguien más barato o el proceso se cancele sin ninguna explicación.📌 “Buscamos el match perfecto”, pero cuando el candidato pide un sueldo acorde a su experiencia, mágicamente el presupuesto se reduce.📌 Piden honestidad en los CVs, pero no dan feedback, no responden mensajes y dejan a los candidatos en el limbo.💡 Entonces, ¿falta talento o falta estrategia en el reclutamiento?Se habla de escasez de talento, pero lo que realmente hay es:🚩 Procesos de selección mal estructurados.🚩 Expectativas irreales y sueldos que no corresponden con la experiencia requerida.🚩 Falta de compromiso con los candidatos.💼 A los reclutadores y headhunters:Si una vacante sigue abierta durante meses o años, tal vez el problema no es el candidato, sino su proceso de selección.Si ya entrevistaron a alguien y no lo seleccionaron, tengan la decencia de darle un cierre honesto en lugar de ignorarlo.No jueguen con el tiempo ni las esperanzas de las personas.📢 Candidatos, ¿les ha pasado? ¿Qué es lo más absurdo que les han dicho en un proceso de selección?Reclutadores, si creen que estoy equivocado, los leo en los comentarios. 👇hashtag#Reclutamiento hashtag#Hiring hashtag#RRHH hashtag#Respeto hashtag#Trabajo 🚀 Lift Others, Rise Together! 🤝🌱 Life is unpredictable, and the person struggling today might be the one hiring you tomorrow💯Unemployment is not just a status—it’s a tough phase filled with uncertainty, self-doubt, and endless job applications. 🌱 Both freshers, experienced professionals, and job changers face struggles that often go unnoticed:💼 Freshers:🔹 Applying to hundreds of jobs, only to be rejected for “lack of experience.”🔹 Struggling to get a response despite having the skills.🔹 Facing interviews where experience is valued more than potential.🎯 Experienced Professionals:🔹 Laid off unexpectedly, forced to start from scratch.🔹 Facing rejections due to “overqualification” or career gaps.🔹 Trying to switch industries but getting stuck in the experience trap.🔄 Job Changers:🔹 Stuck in toxic workplaces but afraid of instability.🔹 Wanting career growth but struggling to find better opportunities.🔹 Finding it hard to convince recruiters about domain changes.💡 What can we do?✅ Accept connection requests from job seekers—they are trying to expand their network, not spam.✅ Refer deserving candidates—a small effort from you can change their life.✅ Share job openings—someone in your network might be the perfect fit.✅ Offer guidance—a simple conversation can boost their confidence.🔄 If you’re hiring, drop a comment below! You don’t need to know everything about AWS, but you should know this.Many people get stuck when starting with AWS because they think they need to master all 200+ services before deploying something to production.The truth? Most web applications use fewer than 10 services.If I had to relearn AWS in a more productive way—beyond just reading the docs and taking AWS courses—I would focus on these:✅ EC2 (Elastic Compute Cloud) – Scalable virtual machines that provide computing power to run applications, offering flexibility in instance types, storage, and networking.✅ ECS (Elastic Container Service) with Fargate – A managed container orchestration service that allows you to run Docker containers without provisioning or managing servers, simplifying deployment and scaling.✅ S3 (Simple Storage Service) – Highly durable and scalable object storage designed for storing and retrieving files, backups, and static content, with built-in security and lifecycle policies.✅ RDS (Relational Database Service) / DynamoDB – RDS provides managed relational databases (MySQL, PostgreSQL, SQL Server, etc.), while DynamoDB is a fully managed NoSQL database optimized for high-performance and scalable applications.✅ Lambda – A serverless compute service that runs code in response to events (like API requests or file uploads) without the need to manage infrastructure, charging only for execution time.✅ API Gateway – A fully managed service that enables developers to create, deploy, and secure APIs at scale, integrating seamlessly with Lambda, EC2, and other AWS services.✅ CloudWatch – A monitoring and observability service that collects logs, metrics, and events from AWS resources, enabling real-time insights, alerting, and troubleshooting.✅ IAM (Identity and Access Management) – AWS’s security framework for managing users, roles, and permissions to control access to AWS resources. Misconfigurations here can lead to serious security risks.✅ SNS (Simple Notification Service) / SQS (Simple Queue Service) – SNS is a pub/sub messaging service for sending notifications, while SQS provides message queuing for decoupling and scaling microservices, distributed systems, and serverless applications.Master these, and you’ll solve 90% of AWS-related problems without needing to memorize everything.AWS is huge, but you don’t need to know it all to be effective. Focus on what matters.hashtag#AWS hashtag#CloudComputing hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#DevOps hashtag#BackendDevelopment hashtag#Cloud hashtag#AWSCommunity hashtag#CloudEngineer hashtag#AWSJobs hashtag#TechCareer hashtag#AWSLambda hashtag#AmazonWebServices hashtag#Hiring hashtag#OpenToWork hashtag#SoftwareDeveloper hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#dotnet hashtag#backend

As part of my AWS training, I gained hands-on experience with 𝗔𝗺𝗮𝘇𝗼𝗻 𝗘𝗕𝗦, 𝗘𝗙𝗦, 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗦𝟯—the core building blocks of AWS storage solutions.𝐊𝐞𝐲 𝐓𝐚𝐤𝐞𝐚𝐰𝐚𝐲𝐬 𝐟𝐫𝐨𝐦 𝐓𝐨𝐝𝐚𝐲’𝐬 𝐋𝐞𝐚𝐫𝐧𝐢𝐧𝐠:✅ 𝗔𝗺𝗮𝘇𝗼𝗻 𝗘𝗕𝗦 (𝗘𝗹𝗮𝘀𝘁𝗶𝗰 𝗕𝗹𝗼𝗰𝗸 𝗦𝘁𝗼𝗿𝗲) – 𝗣𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗲𝗻𝘁 & 𝗛𝗶𝗴𝗵-𝗣𝗲𝗿𝗳𝗼𝗿𝗺𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲 𝗦𝘁𝗼𝗿𝗮𝗴𝗲 🔹 Block-level storage for 𝗘𝗖𝟮 𝗶𝗻𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲𝘀 with multiple volume types. 🔹 Ideal for 𝗱𝗮𝘁𝗮𝗯𝗮𝘀𝗲𝘀, 𝗳𝗶𝗹𝗲 𝘀𝘆𝘀𝘁𝗲𝗺𝘀, 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗺𝗶𝘀𝘀𝗶𝗼𝗻-𝗰𝗿𝗶𝘁𝗶𝗰𝗮𝗹 𝗮𝗽𝗽𝗹𝗶𝗰𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻𝘀. 🔹 Hands-on experience in 𝗮𝘁𝘁𝗮𝗰𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴, 𝗱𝗲𝘁𝗮𝗰𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴, 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗺𝗶𝗴𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝘃𝗼𝗹𝘂𝗺𝗲𝘀 𝗯𝗲𝘁𝘄𝗲𝗲𝗻 𝗶𝗻𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲𝘀.✅ 𝗔𝗺𝗮𝘇𝗼𝗻 𝗘𝗙𝗦 (𝗘𝗹𝗮𝘀𝘁𝗶𝗰 𝗙𝗶𝗹𝗲 𝗦𝘆𝘀𝘁𝗲𝗺) – 𝗦𝗰𝗮𝗹𝗮𝗯𝗹𝗲, 𝗦𝗵𝗮𝗿𝗲𝗱 𝗦𝘁𝗼𝗿𝗮𝗴𝗲 🔹 Fully managed 𝘀𝗲𝗿𝘃𝗲𝗿𝗹𝗲𝘀𝘀 𝗳𝗶𝗹𝗲 𝘀𝘆𝘀𝘁𝗲𝗺, automatically scaling with demand. 🔹 Supports 𝘀𝗶𝗺𝘂𝗹𝘁𝗮𝗻𝗲𝗼𝘂𝘀 𝗮𝗰𝗰𝗲𝘀𝘀 𝗳𝗿𝗼𝗺 𝗺𝘂𝗹𝘁𝗶𝗽𝗹𝗲 𝗘𝗖𝟮 𝗶𝗻𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲𝘀. 🔹 Best suited for 𝗯𝗶𝗴 𝗱𝗮𝘁𝗮 𝗮𝗻𝗮𝗹𝘆𝘁𝗶𝗰𝘀, 𝗺𝗲𝗱𝗶𝗮 𝗽𝗿𝗼𝗰𝗲𝘀𝘀𝗶𝗻𝗴, 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗰𝗼𝗻𝘁𝗮𝗶𝗻𝗲𝗿 𝘄𝗼𝗿𝗸𝗹𝗼𝗮𝗱𝘀.✅ 𝗔𝗺𝗮𝘇𝗼𝗻 𝗦𝟯 (𝗦𝗶𝗺𝗽𝗹𝗲 𝗦𝘁𝗼𝗿𝗮𝗴𝗲 𝗦𝗲𝗿𝘃𝗶𝗰𝗲) – 𝗦𝗲𝗰𝘂𝗿𝗲 & 𝗦𝗰𝗮𝗹𝗮𝗯𝗹𝗲 𝗢𝗯𝗷𝗲𝗰𝘁 𝗦𝘁𝗼𝗿𝗮𝗴𝗲 🔹 Highly 𝗱𝘂𝗿𝗮𝗯𝗹𝗲, 𝘀𝗰𝗮𝗹𝗮𝗯𝗹𝗲, 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗰𝗼𝘀𝘁-𝗲𝗳𝗳𝗶𝗰𝗶𝗲𝗻𝘁 storage for unstructured data. 🔹 Used for 𝗱𝗮𝘁𝗮 𝗯𝗮𝗰𝗸𝘂𝗽𝘀, 𝗹𝗼𝗴 𝘀𝘁𝗼𝗿𝗮𝗴𝗲, 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝘀𝘁𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗰 𝘄𝗲𝗯𝘀𝗶𝘁𝗲 𝗵𝗼𝘀𝘁𝗶𝗻𝗴. 🔹 Hands-on l𝗶𝗳𝗲𝗰𝘆𝗰𝗹𝗲 𝗽𝗼𝗹𝗶𝗰𝗶𝗲𝘀, 𝗽𝗲𝗿𝗺𝗶𝘀𝘀𝗶𝗼𝗻𝘀, 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗮𝗰𝗰𝗲𝘀𝘀 𝗰𝗼𝗻𝘁𝗿𝗼𝗹.𝐏𝐫𝐚𝐜𝐭𝐢𝐜𝐚𝐥 𝐄𝐱𝐩𝐞𝐫𝐢𝐞𝐧𝐜𝐞 𝐆𝐚𝐢𝐧𝐞𝐝: 🔹 𝗖𝗵𝗲𝗰𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗱𝗶𝘀𝗸 𝘂𝘀𝗮𝗴𝗲 & 𝗽𝗮𝗿𝘁𝗶𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻𝘀 using df -h and lsblk. 🔹 𝗔𝘁𝘁𝗮𝗰𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴 & 𝗺𝗼𝘂𝗻𝘁𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗮𝗱𝗱𝗶𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻𝗮𝗹 𝘃𝗼𝗹𝘂𝗺𝗲𝘀 to an EC2 instance. 🔹 𝗨𝗻𝗺𝗼𝘂𝗻𝘁𝗶𝗻𝗴 & 𝗱𝗲𝘁𝗮𝗰𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝘃𝗼𝗹𝘂𝗺𝗲𝘀 and re-attaching them to another instance. 🔹 𝗨𝗻𝗱𝗲𝗿𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗻𝗱𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝘀𝗻𝗮𝗽𝘀𝗵𝗼𝘁𝘀 for backups & disaster recovery.𝐖𝐡𝐲 𝐓𝐡𝐢𝐬 𝐌𝐚𝐭𝐭𝐞𝐫𝐬 𝐟𝐨𝐫 𝐂𝐥𝐨𝐮𝐝 𝐏𝐫𝐨𝐟𝐞𝐬𝐬𝐢𝐨𝐧𝐚𝐥𝐬? 🔹 Efficient storage management ensures high availability & performance. 🔹 Helps in 𝗰𝗼𝘀𝘁 𝗼𝗽𝘁𝗶𝗺𝗶𝘇𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 by selecting the right storage solutions. 🔹 Crucial for 𝗗𝗲𝘃𝗢𝗽𝘀, 𝗖𝗹𝗼𝘂𝗱 𝗘𝗻𝗴𝗶𝗻𝗲𝗲𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴, 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗦𝗲𝗰𝘂𝗿𝗶𝘁𝘆 𝗠𝗼𝗻𝗶𝘁𝗼𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 roles.If you’re looking for 𝗰𝗹𝗼𝘂𝗱 𝗲𝗻𝗴𝗶𝗻𝗲𝗲𝗿𝘀 or 𝗔𝗪𝗦 𝗽𝗿𝗼𝗳𝗲𝘀𝘀𝗶𝗼𝗻𝗮𝗹𝘀 skilled in 𝘀𝘁𝗼𝗿𝗮𝗴𝗲 𝗼𝗽𝘁𝗶𝗺𝗶𝘇𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻, 𝗶𝗻𝗳𝗿𝗮𝘀𝘁𝗿𝘂𝗰𝘁𝘂𝗿𝗲 𝗺𝗮𝗻𝗮𝗴𝗲𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁, 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗰𝗹𝗼𝘂𝗱 𝘀𝗲𝗰𝘂𝗿𝗶𝘁𝘆, let’s connect! 🚀hashtag#AWS hashtag#CloudComputing hashtag#StorageSolutions hashtag#EBS hashtag#EFS hashtag#S3 hashtag#CloudInfrastructure hashtag#DevOps hashtag#Hiring

🌍 Web Development in 2024: Why It's Harder to Relocate & How to Stand Out 🚀The web dev job market is evolving fast, and finding relocation opportunities is tougher than ever. Here’s why and how to stay ahead of the competition.🔥 Why It’s Getting Harder to Relocate✅ Market Saturation – More developers entering the field via bootcamps & self-learning. ✅ Remote Work Expansion – Companies prefer remote hires over relocation costs. ✅ Economic Uncertainty – Startups & mid-sized companies are tightening budgets. ✅ AI & No-Code Solutions – Reducing demand for traditional development tasks.🎯 How to Get Ahead & Land That Job1️⃣ 🚀 Specialize in High-Demand Skills🔹 Instead of being a generalist, go deep into Rust, Web3, AI integrations, or cybersecurity. 🔹 If you already know Laravel, Vue, Node, or React, position yourself as a Rust specialist to stand out.2️⃣ 📢 Build a Personal Brand🔹 Share insights, projects, and industry trends on LinkedIn & Twitter. 🔹 Write blog posts or even create video content on Rust, AI, or full-stack best practices.3️⃣ 🤝 Leverage Networking & Open Source🔹 Engage with Rust & Laravel communities (Discord, GitHub, LinkedIn groups). 🔹 Contribute to open-source projects—many companies hire directly from contributors!4️⃣ 📈 Stay Ahead with AI & Automation🔹 Learn how AI-driven DevOps & automation can boost productivity. 🔹 Companies love developers who understand AI-powered workflows.5️⃣ 🎯 Target the Right Companies🔹 Look for Rust-first startups, fintechs, AI-driven businesses, and blockchain firms. 🔹 Skip mass-market job boards—network directly with hiring managers & founders.🚀 The market is tough, but opportunities are still there for those who stand out. 💬 What’s your strategy for staying competitive in web development? Let’s discuss in the comments! 👇

Dear recruiters, stop looking for candidates with 100% JD match.If someone matches your entire DevOps job description, you're chasing unicorns.Think about it.When you require 10+ years of Kubernetes (a technology from 2014), mastery of 3 different CI/CD tools, 4 logging/monitoring tools, 3 scripting language and expert-level knowledge across AWS, Azure, AND GCP... you're not describing a real candidate.You're describing a fantasy.And what happens when you actually find this rare specimen?They'll probably get bored and leave.The best DevOps engineers I've ever worked with weren't the ones who checked every technical box on day one. They were the ones who:- Demonstrated exceptional problem-solving skills- Had a genuine passion for automating everything- Possessed a "never stop learning" mindset- Understood that reliability matters more than fancy techMost skills in the DevOps world can be learned within weeks by someone with the right foundation.Hire engineers who meet 70-80% of your technical requirements but bring the right mindset.Focus on finding candidates who understand systems thinking, who approach infrastructure as code, who automate relentlessly, and who prioritize reliability. The specific tools are just implementation details.Stop chasing the perfect resume match. Start looking for the perfect mindset match instead.Your infrastructure (and your hiring timeline) will thank you.
